Award.AwardTitle: Problems in Complex Analysis and Complex Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses some fundamental problems that lie at the interface of complex geometry, partial differential equations, and mathematical physics. The unifying theme is complex structures and moduli defined by solutions of partial differential equations, their geometric obstructions, and their singularities. The methods build on the theory of partial differential equations, but the central component will be the development of new techniques and ideas from complex analysis.

Complex structures and moduli first appeared in pure mathematics, but they have since revealed themselves to be at the center of a wide range of phenomena, from applied mathematics to both statistical and high-energy physics. In fact, some of the problems in the present project arise directly from questions about critical phenomena and supersymmetry. Progress in any part of the project should have wide repercussions, both in mathematics and in related fields. The principal investigator has trained a steady stream of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers in the past, and the project will be crucial in allowing him to continue his efforts in this direction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was devoted to the study of some new classes of partial differential equations motivated by complex geometry and the physics of unified string theories. The confluence of these theories can be traced back to supersymmetry and is a relatively recent phenomenon. The solution of the resulting equations requires new methods where hard analysis, differential geometry, and algebraic geometry all play a major role. The main results of the project include the analysis of some basic models including the unstable Kaehler-Ricci flow on the sphere with conic singularities; the introduction of new geometric flows which can help bypass the Kaehler condition when it does not hold; and several new a priori estimates for non-linear partial differential equations. New tools towards the evaluation of superstring scattering amplitudes for higher orders, such as theta identities and formulas for the super period matrix with Ramond punctures, were also developed.
The training of graduate students and mentoring of postdoctoral researchers was an integral part of the project. In particular, 6 students obtained their PhD degrees with theses originating of the project. They are now all active in either academia or industry.
The results obtained have been published on archival journals, and the PI has lectured widely on them.
